description: Software-as-a-Service subscription agreements covering access, usage, support, and service levels

clauses.title: Uptime Service Level
clauses.plainDescription: What percentage of time does the provider commit to keeping the service available?
clauses.legalContext: SLA uptime is a key differentiator in SaaS. 99.9% ('three nines') is standard; 99.99% ('four nines') is premium. Each 'nine' represents roughly 10x less downtime.

options.label: 99.9% (Three Nines)
options.plainDescription: Service available 99.9% of the time - allows about 8.76 hours of downtime per year.
options.legalText: Provider commits to Service Availability of at least 99.9% during each calendar month, calculated as ((Total Minutes - Downtime Minutes) / Total Minutes) Ã— 100%.

options.label: 99.5% Uptime
options.plainDescription: Service available 99.5% of the time - allows about 43.8 hours of downtime per year.
options.legalText: Provider commits to Service Availability of at least 99.5% during each calendar month.

options.label: 99.99% (Four Nines)
options.plainDescription: Service available 99.99% of the time - allows only about 52 minutes of downtime per year.
consPartyB: May be overkill for most uses
options.legalText: Provider commits to Service Availability of at least 99.99% during each calendar month.

options.label: Commercially Reasonable (No SLA)
options.plainDescription: Provider uses commercially reasonable efforts with no specific uptime guarantee.
options.legalText: Provider shall use commercially reasonable efforts to maintain Service availability. No specific uptime percentage is guaranteed.

clauses.title: Support Response Time
clauses.plainDescription: How quickly must the provider respond to support requests based on severity?
clauses.legalContext: Response time SLAs set expectations for support. Faster response typically costs more. 'Response' means acknowledgment, not necessarily resolution.

options.label: Premium (24/7, 1hr Critical)
options.plainDescription: 24/7 support with 1-hour response for critical issues, 4 hours for high priority.
options.legalText: Support available 24/7/365. Response times: Critical (service down): 1 hour; High: 4 hours; Medium: 8 hours; Low: 24 hours.

options.label: Standard (Business Hours, 4hr Critical)
options.plainDescription: Business hours support (M-F 9-6) with 4-hour response for critical issues.
options.legalText: Support available Monday-Friday, 9:00 AM - 6:00 PM (Provider's timezone). Response times: Critical: 4 hours; High: 8 business hours; Medium: 1 business day; Low: 2 business days.

options.label: Basic (Email, 24hr Response)
options.plainDescription: Email-only support during business hours with 24-hour response target.
options.legalText: Support via email during business hours. Provider will use reasonable efforts to respond within 24 business hours.

clauses.title: Customer Data Ownership
clauses.plainDescription: Who owns the data that the customer uploads or creates in the service?
clauses.legalContext: Data ownership is fundamental in SaaS. Customers typically retain ownership while granting the provider a license to host and process. The scope of that license matters.

options.label: Customer Owns All Data
options.plainDescription: Customer retains full ownership of all data. Provider gets only a limited license to provide the service.
consPartyA: No rights to use data beyond service
options.legalText: Customer retains all right, title, and interest in Customer Data. Provider acquires no rights except the limited license to host, process, and transmit Customer Data solely to provide the Service.

options.label: Customer Owns + Provider Uses Aggregated
options.plainDescription: Customer owns their data. Provider may use aggregated, anonymized data for analytics and improvement.
options.legalText: Customer retains ownership of Customer Data. Provider may use aggregated, anonymized data derived from Customer's use of the Service for product improvement and analytics, provided such data cannot identify Customer or individuals.

options.label: Customer Owns + Broad Provider License
options.plainDescription: Customer owns data but grants provider broad license to use for service improvement, analytics, and product development.
options.legalText: Customer retains ownership of Customer Data. Customer grants Provider a worldwide license to use, analyze, and create derivative works from Customer Data for service provision, product improvement, and development of new features.

clauses.title: Termination Rights
clauses.plainDescription: Can the customer terminate the subscription early, and what are the financial implications?
clauses.legalContext: SaaS contracts often restrict early termination to protect provider revenue. The balance is between customer flexibility and provider revenue certainty.

options.label: Locked Term (No Early Termination)
options.plainDescription: Customer cannot terminate early. Full payment required for the subscription term.
options.legalText: Customer may not terminate for convenience during the Subscription Term. Customer remains obligated to pay all Fees for the full term.

options.label: Early Exit with Fee
options.plainDescription: Customer can terminate early by paying an early termination fee (typically remaining commitment or percentage).
options.legalText: Customer may terminate for convenience upon sixty (60) days' notice, subject to payment of an early termination fee equal to fifty percent (50%) of remaining Fees for the term.

options.label: Termination with Notice (No Fee)
options.plainDescription: Customer can terminate with notice period (60-90 days) without early termination fee.
options.legalText: Either Party may terminate this Agreement for convenience upon ninety (90) days' prior written notice. Customer is only obligated to pay Fees through the termination date.

clauses.title: Price Change Notice
clauses.plainDescription: How much notice must the provider give before increasing prices at renewal?
clauses.legalContext: Price change provisions protect customers from surprise increases. Longer notice periods give customers time to budget or seek alternatives.

options.label: 30 Days Notice
options.plainDescription: Provider must give 30 days notice of price changes before renewal.
options.legalText: Provider may modify pricing upon at least thirty (30) days' notice prior to any renewal term.

options.label: 60 Days Notice
options.plainDescription: Provider must give 60 days notice of price changes, providing reasonable planning time.
options.legalText: Provider may modify pricing upon at least sixty (60) days' notice prior to any renewal term.

options.label: 90 Days Notice
options.plainDescription: Provider must give 90 days notice of price changes, allowing substantial planning time.
options.legalText: Provider may modify pricing upon at least ninety (90) days' notice prior to any renewal term.

clauses.title: Auto-Renewal Terms
clauses.plainDescription: Does the subscription automatically renew, and what notice is required to cancel renewal?
clauses.legalContext: Auto-renewal provides continuity but can lock customers in. California Business & Professions Code 17602-17603 requires clear disclosure of auto-renewal terms and easy cancellation procedures.

options.label: Auto-Renew (30 Days Notice to Cancel)
options.plainDescription: Subscription auto-renews for equal periods unless cancelled with 30 days notice.
options.legalText: This Agreement automatically renews for successive periods equal to the initial term unless either Party provides written notice of non-renewal at least thirty (30) days prior to renewal.

CALIFORNIA.warning: California law (Bus. & Prof. Code 17602) requires clear and conspicuous disclosure of auto-renewal terms BEFORE accepting payment. Provider must also provide a cost-effective cancellation mechanism and renewal reminders.

ENGLAND_WALES.note: Consumer Rights Act may apply additional protections for consumer contracts

SPAIN.note: Subject to Spanish consumer protection law for consumer contracts

options.label: Auto-Renew (60 Days Notice to Cancel)
options.plainDescription: Subscription auto-renews unless cancelled with 60 days notice - balanced approach.
options.legalText: This Agreement automatically renews for successive periods equal to the initial term unless either Party provides written notice of non-renewal at least sixty (60) days prior to renewal.

CALIFORNIA.warning: California law (Bus. & Prof. Code 17602) requires clear disclosure of auto-renewal terms and easy cancellation. Must provide renewal reminder and simple cancellation process.

options.label: Manual Renewal Required
options.plainDescription: No auto-renewal. Customer must actively renew the subscription.
options.legalText: This Agreement does not automatically renew. Customer must execute a renewal order to continue the Service beyond the initial term.

CALIFORNIA.note: Avoids California auto-renewal disclosure requirements - simplest compliance approach

clauses.title: Data Export Rights
clauses.plainDescription: What rights does the customer have to export their data, and for how long after termination?
clauses.legalContext: Data portability is critical for avoiding vendor lock-in. The duration of export availability after termination affects transition planning.

options.label: 30 Days Post-Termination
options.plainDescription: Customer data available for export for 30 days after subscription ends.
options.legalText: Upon termination, Provider shall make Customer Data available for export for thirty (30) days. After this period, Customer Data will be deleted.

options.label: 60 Days Post-Termination
options.plainDescription: Customer data available for export for 60 days after termination - reasonable transition window.
options.legalText: Upon termination, Provider shall make Customer Data available for export for sixty (60) days. After this period, Customer Data will be deleted.

options.label: 90 Days Post-Termination
options.plainDescription: Customer data available for export for 90 days - extended window for complex transitions.
options.legalText: Upon termination, Provider shall make Customer Data available for export for ninety (90) days. After this period, Customer Data will be deleted.

clauses.title: Liability Cap
clauses.plainDescription: What is the maximum liability the provider faces for breaches or service failures?
clauses.legalContext: Liability caps in SaaS are typically tied to fees paid. The cap protects providers from catastrophic exposure while giving customers some recourse.

options.label: 12 Months of Fees
options.plainDescription: Each party's liability capped at fees paid in the 12 months before the claim.
options.legalText: Each Party's total cumulative liability under this Agreement shall not exceed the Fees paid or payable by Customer during the twelve (12) months preceding the claim.

options.label: Direct Damages Only (Excludes Indirect)
options.plainDescription: Liability limited to direct damages only. No liability for indirect, consequential, or lost profits.
options.legalText: Neither Party shall be liable for indirect, incidental, special, consequential, or punitive damages, including loss of profits, regardless of foreseeability. Liability limited to direct damages, capped at fees paid in the preceding 12 months.

options.label: Enhanced (Higher for Data/Security Breaches)
options.plainDescription: Standard cap for most claims, but higher cap (2-3x) for data security breaches.
options.legalText: General liability capped at fees paid in 12 months. For breaches of data security obligations, liability capped at three times (3x) fees paid in the 12 months preceding the claim.

clauses.title: Security Standards
clauses.plainDescription: What security certifications or standards must the provider maintain?
clauses.legalContext: Security certifications provide independent verification of controls. Different certifications suit different industries and requirements.

options.label: SOC 2 Type II
options.plainDescription: Provider maintains SOC 2 Type II attestation demonstrating operational effectiveness of controls.
options.legalText: Provider shall maintain SOC 2 Type II attestation covering Security, Availability, and Confidentiality trust service criteria throughout the Subscription Term.

options.label: ISO 27001 Certified
options.plainDescription: Provider maintains ISO 27001 certification - comprehensive information security management.
options.legalText: Provider shall maintain ISO 27001 certification covering the Service throughout the Subscription Term.

options.label: Both SOC 2 and ISO 27001
options.plainDescription: Provider maintains both SOC 2 Type II and ISO 27001 certifications.
consPartyB: May be overkill for some needs
options.legalText: Provider shall maintain both SOC 2 Type II attestation and ISO 27001 certification covering the Service throughout the Subscription Term.

clauses.title: Dispute Resolution
clauses.plainDescription: How and where will disputes about this agreement be resolved? You can choose courts in the governing law jurisdiction, courts elsewhere, or private arbitration.
clauses.legalContext: The forum for disputes is negotiable even though the governing law is fixed. Court litigation is public with appeal rights. Arbitration is private and faster but typically final. For SaaS disputes, arbitration is increasingly popular due to confidentiality.

options.label: Default Courts (Per Governing Law)
options.plainDescription: Disputes resolved in courts of the governing law jurisdiction: San Francisco (California), London (England & Wales), or Madrid (Spain).
consPartyA: May be inconvenient for one party
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be resolved exclusively in the state and federal courts located in the jurisdiction of the governing law. Each Party irrevocably submits to the exclusive jurisdiction of such courts.

options.label: Delaware Courts (Neutral - US)
options.plainDescription: Disputes resolved in Delaware courts, known for sophisticated commercial law and business-friendly judiciary.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be resolved exclusively in the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware (or, if such court lacks jurisdiction, the state and federal courts located in Delaware). Each Party irrevocably submits to the exclusive jurisdiction of such courts.

options.label: JAMS Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Private arbitration under JAMS (Judicial Arbitration and Mediation Services) rules - popular with technology companies and startups.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by binding arbitration administered by JAMS under its Comprehensive Arbitration Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator in the seat of the governing law jurisdiction. The arbitrator's award is final and binding.

options.label: ICC Arbitration
options.plainDescription: International arbitration under ICC (International Chamber of Commerce) rules - the gold standard for cross-border disputes.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration under the Rules of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator, with the seat in the capital of the governing law jurisdiction. The award is final and binding.

options.label: AAA Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Arbitration under AAA (American Arbitration Association) Commercial Rules - well-established with extensive arbitrator network.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration administered by the American Arbitration Association under its Commercial Arbitration Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator in the seat of the governing law jurisdiction.

options.label: LCIA Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Arbitration under LCIA (London Court of International Arbitration) rules - preferred for UK and international commercial disputes.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration under the LCIA Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by a sole arbitrator appointed by the LCIA Court. The seat of arbitration will be London, United Kingdom.
